Though somewhat disturbed at the events which he thus learnt, Gaius regarded the situation as a hopeful one, when* he considered that the Celts were on the road between two hostile armies. He therefore ordered the tribunes to marshal the legions and to advance at the ordinary pace, and in line as far as the breadth of the ground permitted 3 while he himself, having surveyed a piece of rising ground which commanded the road, and under which the Celts must march, took his cavalry with him and hurried on to seize the eminence, and so begin the battle in person, convinced that by those means he would get the principal credit of the action for himself.
